questions.text: The surgeon is doing upper Gl endoscopy. He has crossed the cricopharyngeal sphincter. He saw another indentation in the esophagus. This is related to which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Killian’s dehiscence is situated between?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Following barium swallow picture is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Achalasia Cardia
•    Due to absence of Inhibitory Auerbach’s plexus
•    Secondary achalasia – due to Chagas disease
•    Psudoachalasia: Due to cancer (Cardia > lung)
•    Young age/ Dysphagia - Liquids > solid
•    Increased risk of SCC (In proximal dilated part)
•    X ray- Bird beak sign/ rat tail sign/ sigmoidisation 
•    Manometry – Gold standard (Chicago classification)
•    TOC- Hellers myotomy and Dor (partial fundoplication)
•    POEM (New treatment)

questions.text: A 50 year old female presented with Dysphagia and chest pain. Barium image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Identify the following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is due to persistence of pleuro-peritoneal canals. Let posterior (Bochdalek Hernia) is > 90% and it presents at birth. Right Antero-medial (Morgagni hernia) is rare and it presents in adults. Main content of Morgagni hernia is colon.
Bochdalek hernia is left posterior hernia (M/C- > 90%), presents with respiratory distress after birth. Abdomen is scaphoid and heart is pushed to right side. Pressure ventilation is C/I (No Ambu bag mask ventilation). Ventilation is done by ECMO (Extra-corporeal membrane ventilation). Early repair does not improve survival. Most common cause of mortality is pulmonary arterial HT and pulmonary hypoplasia.
Morgagni Hernia is rare- Presents late in adults. Colon is most common herniated organ.

questions.text: A 48 year old male presented with complains of pain abdomen, vomiting and off and on diarrhoea. His serum serotonin level is high. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
NET (Carcinoid tend to produce chemical mediators e.g. serotonin histamine etc and they cause carcinoid syndrome symptoms like flushing, pain, diarrhoea, dyspnoea, palpitation and pellagra like dermatitis)

questions.text: A 50 year old patient presented with ascites, pain and tenderness over abdomen. Ascitic fluid showed presence of > 600 WBC and 300 Neutrophils/Cmm. What is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is treated by 3rd generation cephalosporin.

choices.text: Order left lateral decubitus view X ray
Get Upper GI endoscopy done to rule out presence of peptic ulcer

questions.text: A 37 year old female with h/o alcohol intake was taking NSAIDS for abdominal pain. She developed severe pain in the whole abdomen. Radiograph is given below. What should be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Air below diaphragm suggests pneumoperitoneum due to bowel perforation. Next step should be resuscitation followed by laparotomy.

choices.text: Tracheal stenosis next step should be bronchoscopy
Tracheo esophageal fistula – Resuscitate and do thoracotomy for repair
Esophageal narrowing- Try endoscopic insertion of naso-gastric tube
Gastric outlet obstruction due to CHPS- should be treated by pyloromyotomy

questions.text: A newborn baby on 2nd day of life was found to have continuous frothing of saliva from the mouth in the emergency. What is the diagnosis and next steps in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
TEF-
•    Most common type C (Proximal atresia)
•    First test- NGT and X ray (Tube stops at 10 cm from incisor)
•    Safest contrast- Iohexol
•    Treatment: 
•    For fit child- Thoracotomy and ligation of fistula with esophageal anastomosis (Cameron Height operation)
•    For low birth weight child + pneumonia- Feeding Gastrostomy and delayed repair

questions.text: 35 years old male with gastric outlet obstruction presented to emergency with multiple episodes of vomiting. Which of the following fluid is preferred for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Gastric outlet obstruction due to recurrent vomiting leads to Hypochloremic hypokalemic alkalosis. Therefore, normal saline is preferred. RL will further increase alkalosis.

questions.text: A female patient after laparoscopic cholecystectomy presented with cystic duct stump leak What should be the immediate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


•    Approach to CBD injury-
•    USG is first step to drain Bilioma
•    MRCP followed by ERCP (or rarely PTC) done to diagnose extent of injury
•    CECT gives best impression of collection
•    Cystic stump blow out treated by stenting of CBD by ERCP (Surgicl re-clipping of cystic duct is another option)
•    CBD perforation is treated by repair over T-Tube
•    CBD transection is best managed by Roux en Y hepatico-jejonostomy.

choices.text: Hepatitis B, C and E markers

questions.text: A 35 year old female presented with right upper abdominal pain. Blood investigations showed Bilirubin 5mg%, Alt 22 IU/L and AST 27 IU/L, ALP was 400 mg%. What should be the next investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
LFT finding is suggestive of obstructive jaundice. It should be managed by USG followed by MRCP.

questions.text: Most commonly used radioisotope in PET scan is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: A patient presented with rectal prolapse. On clinical examination there was a growth at the anal verge which is diagnosed as squamous cell carcinoma of the anal verge. Which of the following is the most adequate treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
SCC of anal canal is treated by Cheo-radiotherapy (Nigro regime).

questions.text: A 3 year old child is brought with history of passage of Greenish yellow faecal discharge from umbilicus. What is most probable embryological cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Patent VID will lead to fecal discharge form umbilicus. 
Patent umbilical end (distal) to VID will cause a discharging umbilical sinus. (Leads to Umbilical adenoma or raspberry tumour)
Patent Proximal end of VID persists as Meckel’s diverticulum.

questions.text: A 5 year old child was brought o the hospital with H/O constipation since birth. He passes stool once a week after taking laxative. There was a history of passage of meconium > 48 hours after birth. What should be next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
History is suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. It should be confirmed by rectal Biopsy (Suction biopsy- full thickness) which is gold standard test. Manometry can also diagnose the condition. Barium enema will tell about the length involved. Ba enema shows a dilated segment followed by a transition zone (usually at rectosigmoid area) followed by a collapsed segment (aganglionic segment). Then it should be treated by surgery- Swenson, Duhamel, Soave, Georgeson or trans-anal endorectal pull through.

questions.text: 35 year old male presented with 1 year history of fever anorexia and weight loss. Contrast image of the bowel is given below. What is the possible diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


The picture is should thin terminal ileum, pulled up ileo-caecal junction and sclerosed cecum- Stirlein sign

questions.text: Identify the pathology shown below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Claw sign of Intussusception
•    Peak incidence age -  6 month- 1 year (Weaning)
•    Frequently occurs infection Adenovirus type 3 virus (lymphoid hyperplasia that act as “lead point” (of Peyer's patch).
•    Rota Virus vaccine can also cause intussusception
•    USG -  Target sign, Pseudokidney sign
•    Ba enema – Claw sign/ Coiled spring sign
•    Ileocolic – Most common type 70% (in children)
•    Colocolic – Most common type in adults
•    Clinical features
    Red Currant Jelly tool
    Sausage shaped or banana shaped lump
    Empty right iliac fossa (Sign of dance)
•    Treatment: 
•    Reduction with air or contrast enema (>70% success)
•    Or Surgical manual reduction should be done urgently  
•    Gangrene starts from the apex

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented with multiple episodes of hematemesis. On admission his vitals are stable and splenomegaly is noted. The mother tells that at birth the boy had developed jaundice and an exchange transfusion procedure had been performed in the same hospital. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Portal vein thrombosis in children is usually due to Umbilical sepsis (Catheterization) during neonatal age. Second main cause is abdominal sepsis. Portal vein thrombosis is the most common cause of portal HT in children. It presents with Splenomegaly and hematemesis due to varices.

questions.text: While performing an appendicectomy, a surgeon encounters a lesion in distal ileum. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Meckel’s diverticulum
•Most common congenital anomaly of GIT
• Persistence of the Proximal end of vitelline duct. 
• At the anti- mesenteric border of the ileum 
Rule of 2- 2% incidence, 2 inches long and 2 feet proximal to the ileocaecal valve. 
• It has its own blood supply, independent of ileum (Vitelline artery)
• Ectopic tissue is commonly found in Meckel's diverticulum (gastric > pancreatic).
• Bleeding is the most common presentation (in children) but obstruction (in adults), 
• The best Investigation is technetium-99m pertechnetate scanning. (technetium scan only shows heterotopic gastric mucosa).
• Contrast studies is best in adults (for Meckels without ectopic gastric tissue)
• Meckles without ectopic tissue should be treated by divertculectomy and with ectopic tissue should be treated by R & A

questions.text: A lady came with right iliac fossa, abdominal ultrasound revealed following findings What is the diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

choices.text: Malrotation of ventral bud of pancreas
Malrotation of dorsal bud of pancreas
Non fusion of duct of Wirsung and duct of Snatorini

questions.text: What is the cause of following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


The image is showing annular pancreas, which is caused by non-rotation of ventral bud of pancreas.

questions.text: A 25-year-old alcoholic male presents with pain in the epigastrium radiating to the back. On examination, there is a lump palpable in the epigastrium. CECT is done and the image is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Pseudo pancreatic cyst

1: It is a collection of fluid around pancreas which develops a reactionary fibrous wall (> 4 weeks).
2: Most common site is lesser sac but may be found anywhere in  retroperitoneum or even in mediastinum or inguinal canal.
3: It does not have epithelial lining. Its has a capsule of Collagen and granulation tissue
4: Causes: Chronic pancreatitis > Acute pancreatitis > trauma (In children Trauma is the most common cause Q)
5: Cyst fluid – High Amylase high with low mucin and CEA (Mucinous cystadenoma has high Mucin and CEA)
6: Most common complication is infection (other complications are Haemorrhage; Obstruction of Duodenum, CBD or GOO; Rupture)
7: Surgery is only done for size of > 6 cm after 6 weeks (normally 8-12 weeks). We wait for 6 week for maturity of wall.
8: Preferred surgery is cystogastrostomy but if the cyst is located below transverse mesocolon then cysto- Jejunostomy should be done

questions.text: A patient presented with left lower quadrant pain. CT picture is given below. Identify the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


    Saw tooth appearance in barium enema/ CT scan
    Common in old age
    West > India (high fiber is protective)
    Involves only colon, Sigmoid is most common site.
    Presents with bleeding or diverticulitis
    Most common vessel to bleed in diverticulosis- Branches of SMA
    Hinchey classification is used for diverticulitis

questions.text: Name the operation shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


The picture is showing Whipple’s operation which is done for pancreatic (Head) cancer. In Whipple’s pancreatico-duodenectomy is done.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female presents to the ER with the chief complaint of bilious vomiting. She has had a history of constipation for the past 4 days. An X-ray of the following patient is taken and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


X ray is showing dilated bowel loops with volvulae conniventes, suggestive of Small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Appendicitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Murphey’s sign is not a feature of appendicitis it is a feature of acute cholecystitis.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiency is seen in a lady with Crohn's disease, in whom the Terminal ileum has been removed?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

choices.text: Right extended hemicolectomy and adjuvant chemotherapy

questions.text: Caecal cancer of Duke’s B2 stage should be treated by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

choices.text: Runs between gall bladder fossa and right hepatic vein
Runs between gall bladder fossa and right branch of portal vein
Runs between gall bladder fossa and IVC containing middle hepatic vein
Runs between gall bladder fossa and left branch of portal vein

questions.text: Which one of the following statements regarding Cantlie's line is correct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: A 45 year old female patient presents with a painless firm abdominal swelling of size 10 x 8 cm near the umbilicus. The swelling can be moved freely in a plane at right angle to the line of attachment of the mesentery. The most probable clinical diagnosis in this patient is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: In Pringle Manoeuvre, clamping of which of the following is not done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Surgery of choice for Type 1 Choledochal cyst is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Which of the following does not come under Ranson’s criteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Ranson’s criteria

choices.text: Charcot’s triad (Intermittent fever with chills + jaundice + pain) + Altered sensorium + Edema.
Charcot’s triad + Edema + Severe anaemia (Hb < 6 gm%)

questions.text: In acute cholangitis Reynold’s pentad consists of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which is not included in quick Sequential Assessment Score (qSOFA)?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

choices.text: Direct Inguinal hernia and sac is lateral to inferior epigastric artery
Direct Inguinal hernia and sac is medial to inferior epigastric artery
Indirect Inguinal hernia and sac is lateral to inferior epigastric artery
Indirect Inguinal hernia and sac is medial to inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the Surgery OPD with a swelling in the inguinal region which reduces with a production of gurgling sound. It disappears completely through the deep ring. What is true about this condition
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Review the image and identify the condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: In familial adenomatous polyposis, which of the following is wrong?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Which of the following investigation cannot be done after Roux en Y gastric bypass?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)
